payload.name: dialectical
payload.core: Advance understanding through structured opposition: state thesis, generate antithesis that genuinely contradicts it, articulate the tension each captures, then synthesize into a position that preserves valid insights from both. Key property: synthesis must be novel (not mere compromise) and testable against original concerns. Repeat until convergence criteria met.

out.d: initial position with explicit claims, scope, and assumptions
opposing position that contradicts thesis on at least one substantive point
structured comparison: what each position captures, what it misses, where they conflict
integrated position transcending the opposition; must address both original concerns without mere averaging
record of rounds, progress metrics, and termination rationale
sharpened definitions emerging from dialectical process

proc: state thesis: write explicit claim with scope (what it applies to) and key assumptions; thesis must be falsifiable
generate antithesis: identify position that contradicts thesis on substance, not style; antithesis must be defensible by reasonable party
articulate tension: for each point of conflict, state (a) what thesis captures, (b) what antithesis captures, (c) why both cannot simultaneously hold
attempt synthesis: propose position that (a) addresses thesis's core concern, (b) addresses antithesis's core concern, (c) is not mere splitting-the-difference
test synthesis: verify synthesis resolves original tension; if it creates new tensions, those become next round's focus
check convergence: apply stopping criteria (see decision_procedure.exit_when); if not met, synthesis becomes new thesis
document round: log thesis, antithesis, tension, synthesis, and progress metric for audit trail

enter_when: two or more defensible positions exist on a substantive question
simple debate produces hardening rather than refinement
conceptual clarity is the goal (not persuasion or winner selection)
parties are willing to revise positions based on argument
exit_when: synthesis addresses both original concerns without creating worse tensions
no defensible antithesis can be generated against current synthesis
3 consecutive rounds produce <10% conceptual change (measured by shared criteria)
time/resource budget exhausted (proceed with best synthesis and flag incompleteness)
stay_in_if: synthesis creates new tensions worth resolving
significant conceptual progress in last round

quick_checklist: Is my antithesis genuinely opposing (not strawman or minor variant)?
Could a reasonable person defend the antithesis?
Have I stated what each position gets RIGHT before attacking?
Does synthesis address BOTH original concerns?
Have I defined when to stop iterating?
check: thesis and antithesis contradict on substance (not just framing)
antithesis is steelmanned: strongest version, not weakest
tension articulated as explicit trade-off with named values
synthesis is testable: criteria exist to evaluate if it succeeds
synthesis is not mere compromise (averaging positions)
convergence criteria defined before starting (max rounds, progress threshold)
each round logged with progress metric
conceptual progress demonstrable (new distinctions, resolved confusions)

common_confusions.why_confused: both structure debate and handle opposing views
common_confusions.distinction: Dialectical: thesis-antithesis-synthesis aiming for conceptual refinement; positions evolve. Argumentation: attack/defense graphs computing which claims survive; positions fixed, only acceptability changes.
common_confusions.test: Are you refining concepts through opposition (dialectical) or computing which fixed claims survive attacks (argumentation)?

common_confusions.distinction: Dialectical: opposition between two positions drives refinement; requires antithesis. Reflective-equilibrium: tension between principles and cases drives adjustment; no opposing party needed.
common_confusions.test: Is there an opposing position you're synthesizing with (dialectical) or tension between your own principles and judgments (reflective-equilibrium)?

common_confusions.why_confused: both involve argumentation and opposing views
common_confusions.distinction: Dialectical: goal is conceptual clarity and synthesis; success = better understanding. Rhetorical: goal is persuasion and belief-change; success = audience adoption.
common_confusions.test: Is your goal to understand better (dialectical) or to convince someone (rhetorical)?

common_confusions.why_confused: common usage treats dialectic as synonym for debate
common_confusions.distinction: Dialectical: collaborative truth-seeking where both parties revise positions. Debate: adversarial contest where parties defend fixed positions to win.
common_confusions.test: Are participants willing to change their position based on the other's arguments (dialectical) or committed to their side (debate)?

diff.paraconsistent: uses contradiction productively to drive synthesis vs tolerates contradiction without resolution
diff.argumentation-theory: refines concepts via thesis-antithesis-synthesis vs computes surviving claims via attack/defense graphs
diff.reflective-equilibrium: opposition between two parties/views vs tension between own principles and cases; dialectical requires antithesis, reflective-equilibrium is self-directed
diff.defeasible: conceptual evolution through synthesis vs formal defeat relations with priority ordering
diff.rhetorical: seeks conceptual clarity via synthesis vs seeks belief-change via persuasion
diff.sensemaking: structured opposition with synthesis goal vs frame-building from ambiguous data; dialectical has explicit adversary, sensemaking does not

fail.desc: Dialectical process cycles indefinitely without synthesis or convergence; positions harden rather than refine; debate becomes adversarial contest rather than collaborative inquiry.
signals: no convergence criteria defined before starting
participants advocate rather than inquire (defend position vs seek truth)
round N+1 thesis identical to round N thesis (no refinement)
more than 5 rounds with <10% conceptual progress

mitigations.how: before first round, define: max rounds (default: 5), progress threshold (default: 10% conceptual change), termination condition (synthesis addresses both concerns)
mitigations.test: written criteria exist before thesis statement; audit can verify

mitigations.how: every 2 rounds, require written synthesis attempt; if synthesis fails, document why and continue
mitigations.test: synthesis document exists after rounds 2, 4, etc.; failure rationale logged if skipped

mitigations.how: after each round, score conceptual progress: new distinctions made, confusions resolved, scope clarified; require >10% improvement to continue
mitigations.test: progress log shows scored metrics per round; <10% triggers convergence check

mitigations.how: before critiquing, state strongest version of opposing view; opponent confirms accurate representation
mitigations.test: antithesis statement includes steelman; opponent sign-off recorded

mitigations.how: participants switch thesis/antithesis roles after round 2; prevents advocacy entrenchment
each round has fixed duration (e.g., 30 min); forced synthesis attempt at timebox end
mitigations.test: timestamps in log show round durations within budget

use: strategy debates where options seem mutually exclusive
resolving conceptual confusion between team members
design critique seeking novel solutions beyond presented options
policy analysis with polarized stakeholder positions
architecture decisions with competing quality attributes

rel.r: tolerates contradiction vs uses it productively
attacks to find weaknesses vs opposition to drive synthesis

ex.sit: Architecture debate: monolith vs microservices for a growing startup.
steps: thesis: 'Monolith first' - reduces operational complexity, faster initial development, single deployment unit. Scope: first 2 years. Assumption: team <10 engineers.
antithesis: 'Microservices from start' - enables independent scaling, team autonomy, technology flexibility. Contradicts: single codebase assumption, shared deployment.

tension: simplicity vs flexibility trade-off. Thesis captures: cognitive load reduction, debugging ease, deployment simplicity. Antithesis captures: scaling independence, team isolation, tech stack freedom.
synthesis attempt 1: 'Modular monolith' - single deployment but internal module boundaries enforced by build system; modules can extract to services later.
test synthesis: addresses simplicity (single deploy), addresses flexibility (module boundaries enable future extraction). Creates new tension: boundary enforcement overhead.
round 2 thesis: modular monolith with lightweight boundaries
round 2 antithesis: boundary overhead negates simplicity gains
synthesis 2: enforce boundaries only at domain aggregate level (3-5 modules max initially); automated boundary checks in CI, not runtime
convergence: synthesis 2 addresses both concerns; no defensible antithesis generated; proceed
ex.insight: dialectical process produced novel 'modular monolith with aggregate-level boundaries' - not in original option set

micro_example.sit: Team disagrees on testing strategy: 'unit tests only' vs 'integration tests only'
micro_example.thesis: Unit tests: fast feedback, isolated failures, cheap to run
micro_example.antithesis: Integration tests: catch real bugs at boundaries, test actual behavior
micro_example.correct_synthesis: Test pyramid with contract tests at boundaries - units for logic, contracts for integration points, few E2E for critical paths. Novel: contract tests address both concerns.
micro_example.key_test: Synthesis must be novel position, not average of inputs
